raw_text:
Based on the paper content, I'll extract the structured information:

```json
{
  "paper_metadata": {
    "title": "Early Life Nutrition and Well-being in Northern Nigeria",
    "matches_expected_title": "NO"
  },
  "program_information": {
    "program_name": "Child Development Grant Program (CDGP)",
    "country": "Nigeria",
    "region": "Northern Nigeria",
    "target_population": "Pregnant women and households in extreme poverty"
  },
  "intervention_components": {
    "component_a_cash_support": {
      "component_a_present": true,
      "cash_support_type": "unconditional cash transfer",
      "cash_amount": "US$22 per month",
      "cash_frequency": "monthly until child turns 24-months old",
      "is_loan_or_credit": "NO",
      "cash_evidence_citation": "The value of the unconditional cash transfer is US$22 per month. This is substantial, corresponding to 85% of women's monthly earnings or 26% of monthly food expenditures. Women can start to receive transfers while the child is in utero until the child turns 24-months old"
    },
    "component_b_assets": {
      "component_b_present": false,
      "assets_provided": [],
      "direct_provision": "NO",
      "assets_evidence_citation": null
    }
  },
  "study_characteristics": {
    "outcomes_measured": [
      "child anthropometrics",
      "health",
      "nutrition",
      "food security",
      "labor supply",
      "income/earnings",
      "business investments",
      "consumption/expenditure",
      "savings/financial"
    ],
    "outcomes_evidence_citation": "We find that at the two-year midline, treated children have a large increase in their HAZ score by 20 relative to those in the control group | Monthly food consumption rises by $21 (25%) after two years | These changes in labor supply and investment in productive assets lead to earnings increases for women of 21% after two years",
    "study_design": "Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT)",
    "design_evidence_citation": "Two thirds of the 210 sample villages are randomly assigned to treatment",
    "is_review_or_policy_analysis": false,
    "publication_year": null,
    "study_conducted_year": "2015-2017",
    "sample_size": 3600,
    "completed": true
  },
  "bonus_information": {
    "has_qualitative_components": true,
    "qualitative_methods": ["qualitative analysis with subset of surveyed households"],
    "qualitative_evidence_citation": "We conducted our evaluation in close collaboration with a parallel stream of qualitative analysis, based on a subset of our surveyed households [Sharp et al. 2018]",
    "has_cost_data": true,
    "cost_mentions": "Cost effectiveness and internal rate of return calculations provided",
    "cost_evidence_citation": "We estimate an internal rate of return of 61% for boys and 36% for girls"
  },
  "evidence_citations": {
    "program_name_citation": "The intervention, known as the Child Development Grant Program (CDGP), is implemented in Northern Nigeria",
    "country_citation": "The intervention, known as the Child Development Grant Program (CDGP), is implemented in Northern Nigeria",
    "target_population_citation": "in our baseline sample, 70% of households live in extreme poverty, infant mortality rates are 90 per 1000 children, and two thirds of young children are stunted"
  }
}
```
